active_learning.discussion_prompt: In a group discussion, debate the trade-offs between IoT convenience (e.g., smart home automation) and security risks. Use examples of real-world breaches (e.g., Mirai botnet) to argue for or against mandating stricter regulations on IoT manufacturers. Link to prior knowledge of basic authentication and network security concepts.
active_learning.peer_teaching: Explain the key concepts to a partner without using technical jargon.
active_learning.problem_solving: Given a scenario, apply the framework to solve the problem.

distractor_protocol.step: Identify common misconceptions about the topic
Ensure distractors are similar in length and complexity
Include partial truths that require deeper understanding

Key vulnerabilities: 1) Weak Authentication/Authorization (default/weak passwords, no MFA). 2) Insecure Network Services (open ports, unencrypted protocols like HTTP). 3) Insecure Interfaces (UI/API flaws). 4) Insufficient Data Protection (unencrypted storage/transmission). 5) Lack of Secure Update Mechanisms (no auto/patched firmware). 6) Physical Security Weaknesses (devices deployed in unsecured areas, no tamper detection, easy access). 7) Supply Chain Risks (compromised components). Threats: Bots (Mirai), DoS, data theft. Mitigations: Change defaults, encrypt (TLS), segment networks, regular updates, physical safeguards, vet suppliers (OWASP IoT Top 10).
